item.title: Separatist Leaders Call for Referendums on Joining Russia
item.description: As Ukrainian forces attempted to reclaim occupied territory, Moscow-backed officials appeared to be speeding up efforts to have parts of Ukraine annexed by the Kremlin.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Bakhmut, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Live Updates: World Leaders Take the Stage at the U.N.
item.description: For the first time in three years, world leaders are convening in New York to discuss sweeping crises that include climate change, food insecurity and the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: U.N. Headquarters in New York City.

item.title: Thousands Pay Tribute as Britain Says Final Farewell to Queen Elizabeth
item.description: More than 100 world leaders, including President Biden, attended the funeral for Queen Elizabeth II, and Britons lined the streets for a procession that took her to her final resting place at Windsor Castle.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times

item.title: Protests Erupt in Iranian Cities After Woman’s Death in Custody
item.description: The 22-year-old’s death sparked outrage across social, religious and political factions. Four people were reported to have been killed by the security forces.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: A protest in downtown Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Egypt Feels Pain of Global Disruptions Wrought by War and Pandemic
item.description: The country’s economy has been very hard hit by cascading crises which have disrupted worldwide trade.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Khaled Desouki/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dates and other dried fruit on sale at a market in central Cairo. In March, the Egyptian central bank devalued the currency by about 14 percent and prices shot up.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth II Is Buried at Windsor Alongside Her Husband, Prince Philip
item.description: After a state funeral at Westminster Abbey and a procession across central London, the British monarch was interred at the King George VI Memorial Chapel.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times

item.title: In One Corner of Kosovo, Cheers Still Ring Out for Putin
item.description: Many ethnic Serbs, nursing grievances against NATO for a 1999 bombing campaign that broke Serbia’s grip on the territory, see President Vladimir V. Putin’s Russia as a potential savior.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Armend Nimani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Statues in Mitrovica honor Prince Lazar, left, a Christian Serb ruler at the Battle of Kosovo in 1389 and Grigory Scherbina, right, a Russian envoy to the region.

item.title: Strike Near Another Ukrainian Nuclear Plant Escalates Fears of Disaster
item.description: A powerful Russian missile hit 300 yards from the plant far from the front lines, Ukraine said, a reminder that despite its recent retreat, Russia can still threaten nuclear sites.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Olga Yakimovich/Reuters
item.media:description: The South Ukraine Nuclear Power Plant in Yuzhnoukrainsk, Ukraine, about 70 miles north of the city of Mykolaiv, in 2015.

item.title: Mexico Has Tequila. Peru, Pisco. In Colombia, a Push for Viche, Now Legal.
item.description: Invented by formerly enslaved people, viche, a cane sugar liquor, was long banned, a sort of Colombian moonshine. Now, it’s a symbol of the country’s often ignored Afro-Colombian culture.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky and Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucía Solís, a sixth generation producer of viche, selling the liquor at the Petronio Alvarez festival in Cali, Colombia, last month.

item.title: U.S. Hostage Exchanged for Afghan Drug Lord in Prisoner Swap
item.description: The Taliban said it had freed an American engineer, Mark R. Frerichs, in exchange for the release of a prominent Afghan tribal leader convicted of drug trafficking.
item.dc:creator: Yaqoob Akbary and Christina Goldbaum
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ebrahim Noroozi/Associated Press
item.media:description: Bashir Noorzai, who was convicted of drug trafficking in the United States in 2008, attends his release ceremony at the Intercontinental Hotel in Kabul on Monday.

item.title: In Ukraine, Glass Is a Precious Substance as Winter Looms
item.description: Russian bombs. Soaring energy costs. Severed trade links. It’s getting hard to fix all the shattered windows in Ukraine, and winter is coming.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workmen installed new windows on the eighth floor of an apartment complex that was damaged by Russian bombings in the northern city of Chernihiv.

item.title: Bus Taking People to Quarantine Crashes in China, Killing 27
item.description: The deaths renewed an anguished debate over the price of China’s “zero Covid” policy.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Yang Ying/Xinhua, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Covid testing site in Guiyang, China, in September. Local officials said they would start sending people elsewhere for quarantine because there were too many for the city’s facilities to accommodate.

item.title: Earthquake Shakes Mexico on Anniversary of 2 Major Temblors
item.description: The magnitude 7.6 earthquake, centered near the boundary of Colima and Michoacan states, killed at least one person. It came on the same day as devastating quakes in 1985 and 2017.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:credit: Jose Mendez/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: People rushed into the streets in Mexico City after a magnitude 7.6 earthquake struck Mexico’s central Pacific coast on Monday.

item.title: Is Choosing Medically Assisted Death Too Easy in Canada?
item.description: Since the government expanded the eligibility for assisted death last year to include those with disabilities, critics have been saying there should be more checks and balances.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Ian Austen/The New York Times
item.media:description: Cheryl Romaire, who wears a fentanyl patch for pain from a degenerative spinal condition, was recently approved for an assisted death.

item.title: 1922: Ex-Kaiser to Marry Princess Hermine
item.description: Wilhelm II, who abdicated as emperor of Germany in the midst of defeat in World War I, had become a widower in 1921.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Sarah Koenig, the Host of ‘Serial,’ Talks About Adnan Syed’s Release
item.description: We talk with Sarah Koenig, host of the “Serial” podcast.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Adnan Syed walking out of the courthouse yesterday.

item.title: How a 79-year-old Film Director Learned to “Fly” on a Trapeze
item.description: Tom Moore made a name for himself as a film, TV and theater director. But his dream has always been to “fly” on the trapeze, high in the air. And that’s what he is doing at age 79.
item.dc:creator: Abby Ellin

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: The funeral of Queen Elizabeth II.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral procession of Queen Elizabeth II yesterday.

item.title: Pentagon Orders Review of Its Overseas Social Media Campaigns
item.description: The move comes after Twitter and Facebook shut down misleading accounts that they determined were sending messages to promote U.S. foreign policy.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon has ordered a review of secretive operations to influence populations overseas after White House officials expressed concerns.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Britain Buries Queen Elizabeth II
item.description: Plus a preview of the U.N. General Assembly and growing nuclear fears in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Queen’s coffin was moved from the gun carriage to a hearse before traveling on to Windsor on Monday.

item.title: Windsor, Queen’s Final Resting Place, Has a Long Association With Her
item.description: Queen Elizabeth spent much time as the castle outside London. Her husband is also buried there.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: As they did in London, crowds gathered on Monday at Windsor Castle to say goodbye to Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: In Parks and on Post Boxes, Crowds Say Farewell to Queen Elizabeth II
item.description: The death of Queen Elizabeth II brought droves of people together in central London, where mourning has distracted many from Britain’s political tumult and cost-of-living crisis.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: After the state funeral service for Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey in London on Monday, her coffin was taken on a gun carriage to Wellington Arch.

item.title: From Coronation to Funeral: Bookends to the Life of a Queen, and a Generation
item.description: For 70 years, Elizabeth II was the anchor of a nation’s identity. Charles III now will take on, or recast, that role.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: PA Images, via Getty Images; Pool photo by Frank Augstein
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth’s coronation in 1953, and her funeral on Monday.

item.title: In the eastern Donbas, a slew of contradictions.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: A road outside Chasiv Yar with mountains of slag visible on the horizon.

item.title: McDonald’s Begins to Reopen Restaurants in Ukraine This Week
item.description: Three outlets will open in Kyiv for delivery, before a wider reopening in the capital and west of the country over the next two months.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Simonetti
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: All 109 McDonald’s restaurants in Ukraine closed after Russia invaded in February.

item.title: Thousands Gather in Hyde Park to Watch Queen Elizabeth's Funeral
item.description: Tens of thousands of people gathered in the park in central London to watch Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral service.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Justin Tallis/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Crowds watched the funeral service on Monday on a screen at Hyde Park in London.

item.title: Crowds Gather in Windsor to Await the Arrival of the Queen’s Coffin
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II will be interred in St. George’s Chapel at Windsor Castle later on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Throngs of people waited along the Long Walk at Windsor Castle on Monday.

item.title: Where Will the Queen Be Buried?
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II spent much of the pandemic at Windsor Castle. She will be interred in the King George VI Memorial Chapel, next to Prince Philip, her husband of 73 years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Long Walk to Windsor Castle on Monday morning.

item.title: Democracy Challenged
item.description: Representative government faces its most serious threats in decades.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Kahn

item.title: Europe’s Energy Crisis Forces Factories to Go Dark
item.description: Manufacturers are furloughing workers and shutting down lines because they can’t pay the gas and electric charges.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glass stems on a conveyor belt at Arc International in France. The company needs natural gas to make its glassware, but Europe’s energy crisis has caused gas prices to surge.

item.title: Jenny Xie Explores the Subversive Power of the Concealed and the Overlooked
item.description: In her new poetry collection, “The Rupture Tense,” Xie peeks at the past — her family’s, and China’s — to examine the consequences of “how we see, what we see, and also what we allow to remain unseen.”
item.dc:creator: Han Zhang
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: “A lot of things remained hidden by people who became accustomed to living inside these dead silences,” Xie said.

item.title: Widespread business and public service closures put Britain’s economy on hold.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The line to view the queen’s coffin curled past the City of London on Sunday. Schools and workplaces are closed on Monday for the funeral, as well as businesses including restaurants, gyms and stores.

item.title: What Time Is Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral?
item.description: The funeral for Queen Elizabeth II will begin at 11 a.m. on Monday, followed by a procession across central London.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II has been lying in state at Westminster Hall since Wednesday. A procession will accompany the queen’s coffin from Westminster Hall to Westminster Abbey on Monday morning.

item.title: How to Watch Queen Elizabeth II’s Funeral
item.description: The New York Times will feature a livestream of the main events.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Yoan Valat/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Watching a broadcast of the procession of the coffin containing the body of Queen Elizabeth II as it arrived from Buckingham Palace at Westminster Hall in London on Wednesday.

item.title: Ukrainian officials try to build pressure to hold Russia accountable for war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Ron DePasquale and Juston Jones
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian investigators at a grave site in Izium, Ukraine, on Saturday.

item.title: Who Is Attending the Queen’s Funeral
item.description: President Biden will be among the 2,000 mourners at the funeral for Queen Elizabeth II at Westminster Abbey.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Queen Elizabeth II last year at Windsor Castle.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Pressure on Russian forces in southern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian forces moving near the Kherson front this month. Officials claim they are making slow, hard-fought but steady gains.

item.title: Queen Elizabeth: A Visual Dictionary
item.description: The things that made the queen the queen.
item.dc:creator: Louis Lucero II
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Rebecca Naden

item.title: Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Forces Face Mobilized Inmates and Drones
item.description: Ukraine has been pushing a counteroffensive in the east and south, applying greater pressure to Russian forces, but there is no indication of any mass Russian withdrawal.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in front of a hotel in Kramatorsk on Sunday. It was struck by a Russian missile overnight.

item.title: Biden Pays Homage to Queen Elizabeth as ‘Decent, Honorable’
item.description: The U.S. president will be one of dozens of world leaders attending the funeral on Monday for a royal who had ruled for nearly as long as the president has lived.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden signing the official condolence book for Queen Elizabeth II at Lancaster House in London on Sunday.

item.title: The Singular Offense of the Mass Grave
item.description: Violent loss is even more devastating when the dead are disposed of without identification. When Russians pull out in Ukraine, they leave a trail of anonymous death.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Numbers, not names, on makeshift grave markers near Izium last week.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Queen Elizabeth II’s Funeral
item.description: Plus a powerful typhoon lashes Japan and cheetahs return to India.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered in the streets around Parliament Square in Westminster on the day ahead of the funeral of Queen Elizabeth II in London on Sunday.

item.title: Guest List for Queen Elizabeth’s Funeral Includes Everyday Honorees
item.description: Among those invited to Queen Elizabeth II’s funeral are almost 200 people who were honored for various forms of public service this year.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain

item.title: Exhumations in Izium will continue for two more weeks, its mayor says.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian investigators at a large grave site in the forest by Izium, in northeastern Ukraine. Russian soldiers occupied the city for six months before fleeing last week.

item.title: Alla Pugacheva, Russian Pop Star, Comes Out Against Ukraine War
item.description: Alla Pugacheva, whose stardom has spanned from the Soviet era to after the Cold War, said the invasion of Ukraine had turned Russia into a “pariah.”
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Anton Belitsky/Epsilon via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Russian singer Alla Pugacheva in Moscow in 2011. The war, she wrote in a post on Instagram, was “turning our country into a pariah and worsening the lives of our citizens.”

item.title: A Russian attack during an evacuation of psychiatric patients kills four Ukrainian health care workers.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Ukraine’s Military Says Iranian Attack Drones Have Reached the Battlefield
item.description: A Ukrainian colonel said attacks that took out howitzers and armored vehicles were carried out by Iranian-made drones that had not previously been used outside of the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: Pelosi, in Armenia, Condemns Azerbaijan Over Clashes
item.description: Fighting last week, the deadliest between the two countries since 2020, was “initiated by the Azeris,” Speaker Nancy Pelosi said, while also calling for a negotiated settlement.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Karen Minasyan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi, center, on Sunday at the Tsitsernakaberd Armenian Genocide Memorial Complex in Yerevan, the capital.

item.title: The View From Russia
item.description: Russians near Ukraine are starting to hear the sound of explosions, and their worries are growing.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Refugees arrive from the Kharkiv Region of Ukraine to a temporary camp in Belgorod, Russia, on Wednesday amid the Ukrainian counteroffensive in the region.

item.title: Powerful Typhoon Thrashes Japan, With Millions Told to Evacuate
item.description: The storm, called Nanmadol, carried gales and heavy rain as it was expected to creep up nearly the entire length of the country.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and John Yoon
item.media:credit: Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: High waves hitting the shore on Sunday in Miyazaki, in southern Japan.

item.title: A Welsh Village Embraces Its Bond With the Queen
item.description: A disaster at Aberfan, a small Welsh community, almost 60 years ago forged an unusual link between the community and the queen. The atmosphere there today — quiet grief coupled with brief flashes of dissent — encapsulates the national mood.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Mary Turner
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Moy Road in Aberfan, the site of a school and several houses that were destroyed during an avalanche that killed 116 children and 28 adults in a disaster in October 1966.

item.title: How Russian Trolls Helped Keep the Women’s March Out of Lock Step
item.description: As American feminists came together in 2017 to protest Donald Trump, Russia’s disinformation machine set about deepening the divides among them.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Taiwan, Killing at Least 1
item.description: A southeastern county was shaken by a strong temblor for the second day in a row.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:credit: Ritchie B Tongo/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: In South Korea, President Yoon Treads Fine Line Between U.S. and China
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol has aligned his country more closely with the United States, but there are limits to how far he can go without angering China or provoking North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea.

item.title: Biden Warns Russia Against Using Unconventional Weapons
item.description: Some officials worry that the more cornered Vladimir Putin feels, particularly with recent setbacks from Ukraine’s counteroffensive, the greater the chance that he might turn to an unconventional weapon.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Norimitsu Onishi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency services workers collecting unexploded ordnance from the side of the road near Izium on Saturday.
